'''''Mycena clariviolacea''''' is a [[mushroom]] in the [[Mycenaceae]] family.<ref name=Fungorum/> First reported as a new species in 2007, it is known only from [[Kanagawa]], Japan, where it fruits on dead fallen twigs in forests dominated by [[oak]] and [[Castanopsis|chinquapin]] trees. Distinctive features of this species are found in its medium-sized, dark violet [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]], with [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] up to {{convert|25|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter and slender [[stipe (mycology)|stems]] that are about {{convert|30|to|40|mm|in|abbr=on}} long. Microscopic characteristics include the amyloid [[spore]]s (staining when treated with [[Melzer's reagent]]), the club-shaped cheilocystidia ([[cystidia]] on the gill edge) that are covered with one or more, knob-like, apical protuberances, the absence of pleurocystidia (cystidia on the gill face), and the cylindrical, [[diverticulum|diverticulate]] caulocystidia (cystidia on the stem).

==Taxonomy, naming, and classification==
The mushroom was first collected by Japanese mycologist Haruki Takahashi in 2000, and, along with seven other ''Mycena'' species, was reported as a new species in a 2007 publication. The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] is derived from the [[Latin]] words ''clari-'' (meaning "clear") and ''violacea'' ("[[wikt:violaceous|violaceous]]"). The Japanese name is ''Shikon-sakuratake'' (シコンサクラタケ).<ref name=Takahaski2007/>

According to Takahashi, the amyloid spores, the cheilocystidia covered with one or more, knob-like, apical excrescences, the diverticulate elements in the cortical layer of [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] and [[stipe (mycology)|stem]], and the diverticulate caulocystidia suggest that the species is best [[classification (biology)|classified]] in the [[section (biology)|section]] ''Fragilipedes'', as defined by the Dutch ''Mycena'' specialist [[Rudolph Arnold Maas Geesteranus|Maas Geesteranus]].<ref name=Takahaski2007/><ref name=MaasGeesteranus1980/>

==Description==

Depending on the age of the mushroom, the [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] can range in shape from conic to convex to bell-shaped to somewhat flattened in age; it reaches {{convert|10|to|25|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter. It is sometimes shallowly [[wikt:umbilicate|umbilicate]] (with a small depression like a navel), radially grooved almost to the center, and somewhat [[hygrophanous]] (changing color as it loses or absorbs water). The cap surface is dry, and [[wikt:pruinose|pruinose]] (covered with what appears to be a fine white powder), but this soon sloughs off, leaving the surface smooth. Initially, the cap color is dark violet, but it later fades to grayish-violet around the edges. The whitish [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is up to 0.5 mm thick, and lacks any distinctive taste or odor. The slender [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is {{convert|30|to|40|mm|in|abbr=on}} long by {{convert|1|to|3|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} thick, cylindrical, centrally attached to the stem, and hollow. Its surface is dry, pruinose over the entire length, and grayish-violet to dark violet in color. The base is covered with a white mycelial [[wikt:tomentum|tomentum]] (a hairy covering of short, closely matted hairs). The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] are adnate (fused to the stem), and distantly spaced, with about 15–19 gills reaching the stem. The gills are up to {{convert|2.5|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} broad, thin, and the same color as the cap or paler.<ref name=Takahaski2007/>

===Microscopic characteristics===
The [[spores]] are broadly [[wikt:ellipsoid|ellipsoid]], smooth, colorless, [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]] ([[staining]] bluish to blue-black when treated with [[Melzer's reagent]]), thin-walled, and measure 8–9 by 5–6 [[micrometre|µm]]. The [[basidia]] are 40–60 by 10–12 µm, club-shaped, and four-spored. The cheilocystidia ([[cystidia]] on the gill edge) are abundant, club-shaped, and measure 30–45 by 10–17 µm. Their tips are covered with one or more, knob-like short excrescences that are colorless and thin-walled. Pleurocystidia (cystidia on the gill face) are absent. The [[hymenophore|hymenophoral]] tissue (tissue of the [[hymenium]]-bearing structure) is made of thin-walled hyphae that are 12–21 µm wide, cylindrical (but often somewhat inflated), smooth, and contain cytoplasmic brownish pigment. These hyphae are dextrinoid, meaning that they stain reddish to reddish-brown in Melzer's reagent. The [[pileipellis|cap cuticle]] is made of parallel, bent-over hyphae that are 2–7 µm wide, and cylindrical. These hyphae are smooth, or can be covered with scattered, warty or finger-like thin-walled [[diverticulum|diverticulae]] that are colorless or pale brownish, and dextrinoid. The layer of hyphae underlying the cap cuticle is parallel, cylindrical, hyaline or brownish, and dextrinoid; it has short and inflated cells that are up to 48 µm wide. The stem cuticle is made of parallel, bent-over hyphae that are 3–8 µm wide, and similar to the hyphae of the cap cuticle. The caulocystidia (cystidia on the stem) are 45–88 by 5–8 µm, cylindrical, diverticulate, colorless or brownish, and thin-walled. The flesh of the stem is composed of longitudinally running, cylindrical hyphae that are 8–25 µm wide, smooth, colorless, and dextrinoid. [[Clamp connection]]s are present in the cap cuticle, the stem cuticle, the gill flesh, and at the basal [[septum|septa]] of the basidia.<ref name=Takahaski2007/>

===Similar species===
''Mycena clariviolacea'' is similar to the Brazilian species ''[[Mycena cerasina|M. cerasina]]'' and the European ''[[Mycena diosma|M. diosma]]''. ''Mycena cerasina'', which belongs in the section ''Cerasinae'' of the genus ''Mycena'', differs in having a grayish-purple cap and stem, and forming somewhat [[wikt:utriform|utriform]] ([[wineskin]]-shaped) to [[wikt:lageniform|lageniform]] (flask-shaped), smooth cheilocystidia. ''Mycena diosma'', classified in the section ''Calodontes'', subsection ''Purae'', may be distinguished microscopically from ''M. clariviolacea'' by its smooth, spindle-shaped cheilocystidia and pleurocystidia, and nondiverticulate hyphae in the cortical layer of cap and stem.<ref name=Takahaski2007/>

==Habitat and distribution==
''Mycena clariviolacea'' is known only from [[Kanagawa]], Japan. Fruit bodies are found growing solitary or scattered, on dead fallen twigs in forests that are dominated by [[oak]] and [[Castanopsis|chinquapin]] trees. The mushroom fruits from June to September.<ref name=Takahaski2007/>
